title: Very poor service
body:
Arrived at 8.20am with only 3 other patients in front of me. Was seen by a nurse immediately. Was finally seen by a doctor at 10.30am when I was rushed in and out. 
Whilst waiting it became obvious to me that even though the service opens at 8am, the doctors start anytime after 9am.

title: Fantastic staff
body: Just can't say enough about the staff here, everyone has been absolutely amazing, we have been here for almost a week and I feel upset that I can't say thank you to everyone we have had look after us from the Labour ward to the ladies in the neonatal unit. Everyone on the ward we were on (314) are just brilliant at their jobs and so happy to support you if you have any issues, panic about anything or just want some general advise. So glad I had my little man here ❤

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Bad experience
body:
My son was seen by a nurse practitioner and was very upset by the way he was treated. He suffers from anxiety and it took 
a lot to even go to the appointment, he was made to feel like he was wasting their time. It was a bad experience.

title: Impossible to get an appointment
body: I have never been able to get an appointment at this GP surgery. You ring one day and they tell you to ring the next morning. You ring the next morning and they tell you that all of the appointments are gone. This is the opinion of many of my peers, in that it is extremely hard to book an appointment.

title: Upsetting
body: My husband had a stroke , I acted fast , the ambulance acted fast , then we get to hospital and wait outside in the ambulance for hours , even moving ambulances because ours went off shift , my husband has another stroke in ambulance so he’s taken in with permission to go in ,He is  taken to cubicle , waited another hour before seen , even though husband having another turn , then we are told there’s a 4 hour time slot for treatment for stokes and we are over that time slot , so angry as we were at the hospital outside in a ambulance all that time missing this time slot for treatment, it is drummed into you to act fast and then you are let down by not being able to get into the hospital for the desperate help needed

author: Anniedfg
title: I hope this company can learn from listening
body:
I feel unheard and I listened for the lack of thought or care provided by Crimson Hill Support in North Petherton.  
My support workers are wonderful, but when I became really unwell lately, they withdraw my allocated support hours without a reason.  
My support workers raised concerns with the private support company and neither of us were listened to or given any proper answers.  
I have deteriorated badly since they pulled my care leaving me to struggle and manage without any explanations from the care company.  
To leave people unable to cope to the point of crisis is in my view really poor management.  
The company are employed to take care of people with learning disabilities and mental health care needs, but just seem not to listen or want to put things right when things go wrong. They seem to blame the person, rather than meet to discuss ways to amend.  
I would not recommend this company to anyone I know, until they put right, sometimes serious concerns.  
The support workers I spoke to feel they are unheard, and not taken seriously and ignored making them wish they could leave.  
It is unsatisfactory.  
I hope this company can learn from listening in the future, to help improve patient experiences.

author: KeepSwimming
title: Safety, solace and recovery
body:
I recently suffered with my mental health and ended up as an informal patient at a local hospital on their acute mental health ward at Calverton Hill. I was feeling very vulnerable and distressed and didn't know quite what to expect. I spent just over three weeks on the ward before returning home.  
There is no doubt that the priority was my personal safety, making sure that I was given the time and space to allow me to recover enough to return home and that was certainly achieved. I was lucky to have my own room and toilet/ washing facilities, along with a communal lounge. I was thoroughly checked over by a doctor and nurse on my arrival and it was made clear that all the staff were there to provide support.  
Unfortunately this was not the case. Arriving on a ward like this was distressing, with very little information about what was happening, what was expected of me and I felt I had very little control over my life. When I was distressed, some staff were fantastic, supportive, ready to listen and proactive. However, many of the staff seemed to be either distracted by those patients with greater needs or simply disinterested in the patients, particularly in the evenings.  
I had to ask for my care plan to be completed, and this felt like a copy and paste exercise from other patients' plans and included numerous errors. I raised this twice with the nurse but it seems I was expected to try and catch them to identify the errors, rather than this being their responsibility. I received this plan a week before I was discharged due to 'an issue with the printer in the office'. Only later on, relying on the support of my family and friends, did I feel sufficiently able to voice my concerns, but many of the actions requested by the consultant in the ward rounds were not followed through. For example, I had stated that I found it helpful to have 1:1 conversations as talking therapy, following the support I had received from my local crisis team (who were fantastic). The doctor requested that every day I have a 20 minute 'slot' for discussion with any member of staff. This did not happen once in all the time I was there.  
Bags were not thoroughly checked and I have no doubt that I could have further harmed myself had I decided to do so. I admit I did at times take in my own painkillers to help me manage pain and this was not noticed by the staff. Being awoken by a light every two hours as part of safety checks led to my first migraines in over a year. I asked for this to stop but unless I placed a note outside my room, this practice continued. These are just a few examples of numerous concerns and issues with my care.  
Those of us who feel vulnerable are often withdrawn and unable to ask for help. Being placed in an environment that was unstructured, disorganised and at times felt uncaring made me feel angry and frustrated. I felt that because I was quiet and slept, little effort was made to engage with me or support me, and the quality of support I received depended very much on who I was dealing with.  
Keeping someone safe involves more than leaving them to sleep quietly in a risk assessed environment, monitoring and managing things purely from a pharmaceutical perspective. There was little treatment on offer that differed from strategies I was already trying and I felt no attempt to work towards a discharge other than a reliance on my own determination to get out as quickly as possible. My appointment with the psychologist was due to take place on the day of my discharge.  
I hope that things improve very soon for the lovely people who are left on the ward and am grateful to the few good staff who helped make my stay more bearable. In my feedback, I've asked if I can speak to the hospital about my care.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: The old lock keeper
title: No Gp appointments
body:
I have been trying to get an appointment to see a GP since before Christmas! Finally got an appointment (a fifteen day wait) only to be told I would have to see a nurse because they don’t have a GP on the day of my appointment!  
I am leaving this practice today!

title: Amazing care
body: After attending the qeqm hospital, I would just like to say how impressed I was with all the medical staff from the ambulance service, resuscitation room, through to the observation ward. Every single person who helped me in my time of need were extremely kind, compassionate and professional. I cannot thank them enough.

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

author: ABone
title: staff were great
body: I was a recent inpatient is ward 5c, the nursing staff were great and attended to all my needs when clearly under pressure due to staffing. I would like to thank Ian and Thomas who were very helpful throughout my stay.

title: Extremw Professionalism by the nurse
body:
I would like to inform that my recent visit to the surgery (although I prefer to be seen by a doctor) I was seen by the nurse and what a professional he is.He didn't rush me, he really listened to me and looked interested, also although I am not a doctor my self I can tell for sure he transparanted that he really knows what he is doing, very knowledgeable nurse.If next time I need an appointment for my GP I can say clearly that if my GP won't be available I would like to be seen by him.

Kind Regards 

Isabel Brilha

title: Impressed
body: I was admitted to the medical day unit on floor 1 for a biopsy. The treatment was efficient from start to finish. Nursing care was excellent, the ward was kept very clean and the ladies who cleaned, brought food and tea were friendly and helped put me at my ease. Thank you to all the staff concerned for their care.

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Great Practice - Great Reception - Great Doctors
body: I wanted to share my experience and give feedback on the Mortimer Surgery. The whole team from the reception to the doctors to the physio's are amazing. So caring, friendly and professional. The call back service is excellent and they always make an effort to see you even if they are busting at the seems with clients. Thank you to the doctor for sorting my bronchitis out so quickly. Really made all the difference. Thank you all x

title: Sometimes falls short
body: I’m deaf so calls difficult. To get an appointment I am forced to receive a call from Triage and then they decide if I see a doctor. Waste of time and resources. New doctors don’t read notes where it clearly states I am deaf, yet most don’t face me when speaking . One senior Doctor has always been excellent. My previous GP here left ( I wasn’t told) and I’m allocated another Doctor without my knowledge. I find that unacceptable. Getting an appointment is virtually impossible unless you wait 2 weeks or more. I’ve also been told by reception that a group of appointments ‘ have not been released yet’ and awaiting permission from Practice Manager to do so. Have been asked what my symptoms are by a receptionist , who didn’t like my reply of ‘ not your business unless your medically qualified’. Not been asked since . Shambolic at times with the Dentist shouting patients names, whilst some Doctors barely raise a whisper when calling your name. Last visit a screaming child drowned out everything and went on for 20 minutes . My appointment was almost an hour late and I only got relief from the screaming child when I was finally seen . Yet I have been late arriving on just one occasion by 10 minutes due to traffic and received a lecture from reception. Came out to the child still screaming ( he had been prevented from running riot by his mother) various frowns from reception but nothing actually said . All in all it’s gone from having a system that worked pretty well ( phone at 8 for an appointment) to one that does not work well, by having to go through triage. Even then I was only given an appointment with practitioner nurse , who although nice, had limited capabilities in dealing with my problem, resulting in my having to visit the surgery again today to see the doctor

title: Circus
body: None of the doctors seem to have an interest in communicating with each other to help patients, infact the three doctors don't even seem to like each other and often show obvious signs of disharmony between them resulting in a disservice to their patients.

title: Incredibly quick
body: We had to go to urgent care in Tiverton after our friend cut his hand. We were seen incredibly quick and he was happy with the treatment.

title: Great treatment
body: I came in on 09/02/2020 at 12.30 for blood test. The Trainee Nurese Associate was brilliant. In all the years I have been for blood tests, the nurses have not managed to get blood from my arms, and have resulted in taking it from my hands. The nurse took blood from my arm in her first attempt. We were in and out of the surgery in 10 minutes from the time we checked in. She is a great asset to the surgery

title: User busy all the time!
body:
I went in on Friday after registering and tried to book an appointment at the desk but was told they can’t do that I have to call Monday morning at 8 am. 

So here I am today calling them at 8 and have been trying to for the last 40 minutes just to constantly get user busy! Meaning the phones off the hook! I mentioned it was for my mental health which I said was get very bad and that I need to regain my therapist. But no here I am no answers and not even ringing I think I’ll find a different gp please avoid

title: Rude receptionist
body: My boyfriend suffers badly with his mental health and called for an emergency appointment to see a doctor he is familiar with who knows him, to be told very abruptly by the receptionist that mental health is not an emergency and if he feels his is he should go to a&e!! I accompanied him to an appointment last week where he broke down and was very upset and the doctor requested I call on Monday to book him an appointment for Friday to be seen by her so she could keep an eye on him. I rang continuously for 15 minutes to then have the same rude receptionist interject the conversation I was having with someone else to say I couldn’t book an appointment for Friday even though this was what the doctor had asked. They were extremely rude and abrupt and didn’t care when I said I’d be making a complaint either, apparently it was “not a problem”

title: first class service
body: Visited Haematology on a very busy Friday morning - ticket number 72 with about 25 patients before me in the queue. Staff very friendly and quick to put patients at ease.  The member of staff who took my bloods very professional - please pass on my sincere thanks to all the team.

title: Outstanding
body: Had an injury from sports, having been Newton abbot and diagnosed minor break I was still in pain so went Cumberland. Outstanding treatment was listened to properly had both arms checked properly and reslung. X-rays were requested and they straight away noticed major break and referred to fracture clinic. In and out within two hours. Amazing treatment

author: BT000
title: Chilled experience
body: Baby massage was a lovely chilled experience. Really enjoyed the course.

author: RK000
title: Baby Massage
body: A fantastic course that has really helped with mu son's colic symptoms and a lovely way for us to bond together.

title: Great Surgery - great service
body: I always find it easy to access advice and appointments when required, plus the ask my gp online service is great.  When I have made appointments they always appear to keep to a good schedule and see me in a timely manner.  The GPs I have seen treat me as an individual and allow me to ask questions and discuss my treatment/management.  Ive always fond reception and pharmacy staff really helpful and responsive.  I think its a great surgery and they do a great job.  I would strongly recommend this surgery to anyone local.

author: IJ000
title: We both really enjoyed this
body: Baby Massage - Really helped to relax my child before bed time, also helped with constipation. We both really enjoyed this.

title: Awful telephone system
body: I got on the phone to make an appointment at 8am when the lines open and an hour later still not got through. They put you on hold which is fine, but after 18 minutes the system cuts you off and you have to go through the whole thing again. I have been cut off 3 times now before giving up.

author: EC000
title: Helps with bonding
body: Baby massage - Excellent service helps with bonding and can help with minor medical problems, I. e. constipation, colic. Really enjoyed bringing my daughter and it has helped the bond we have together.

author: Lachlan
title: My pregnancy
body:
I was under the care of oban maternity unit for both my pregnancies and what fantastic care every midwife and assistant in the maternity unit delivered. They made me feel so calm, relaxed and comfortable at all my appointments- NOTHING was ever a bother for them. It was always a very happy environment to be in.  
Mairead especially(my midwife) went above and beyond making sure I had the best pregnancy and birthing experience possible which I did thanks to her! She is a wonderful person and any lady is lucky to have her as a midwife.

author: Patient 54321
title: Much more efficient
body: I had an accident at work when I tripped and fell over.   I was seen very quickly by extremely friendly and welcoming staff.   Taken though for X-rays and given medication for the pain.   I found the new process much more efficient than sitting waiting in A& E.

title: Best practice!
body:
This is the best practice I’ve ever been to. Always great care from the friendly, reception staff and really understanding and patient doctors there. 
Highly recommended.

title: Disappointed
body: It is an effort to get an appointment even at 8am start of call. You would wait 30mins + only to find out there is no more appointment available. You do another day with the same problem and again. I tried to explain my condition hoping to get an appointment but all you get is a no straight away. I wish GPs will put a qualified staff to assess complaints. A receptionist wont be able to do this. Or at least receptionist should be trained to pass patient's complaints to the doctors so the doctor can prioritise who to see. It's becoming like a 'wish-me-luck' game. I was told that there was only 1 doctor available, hence, phone not answered????

author: lynnep
title: My sons day surgery
body: My son was admitted for day surgery, staff on that day could not do enough as my son has autism and anxiety was really bad. From arriving until leaving all staff were consistent in their high level of care, communication was fantastic from all staff again, Dr Kubba, ENT and staff at 1b and all involved.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Pricilla
title: Breast cancer
body: I was diagnosed with breast cancer in January 2020. Totally devastated I could barely take it in. 3 weeks & 2 days later I have had my operation. We are all guilty of complaining about the NHS but I cannot praise it enough. When I needed it everything was done very quickly. Clinic appointments & then surgery all taken care of very quickly. Every member of staff has been very kind & understanding. I cannot thank these people enough. I still have more treatment ahead of me but I have confidence that I will have the very best of care.

title: Getting through on phone is awful, limited…
body:
The doctors are caring. The reception staff are friendly and polite. But it is a struggle to deal with the practice on an admin level. I can’t do what I need to online and every time I have trouble getting through on the phone. I have had admin problems with repeat prescriptions and the appointments to see nurse or doctor are very limited. 

ICO, please also drop or allow a bypass to the too long recorded message when you dial in. Including your message, I have spent 45 minutes in the queue on the phone to get through today so far just to speak with your switchboard.

title: Disgusting not yet seen a GP
body: Can't get an appointment(to see a GP).I have a cronic kidney disease and have had a brain heamorrage within the last 12 months. Was forced to change GPs after moving house. According to the NHS website this surgery has 2 registered doctors for 15000 patients and are still taking on more but I can never see a GP. I am changing GPs. The staff on the phones are insulting and uncaring and the NHS should investigate as the reviews if this place tell the story. An insult to patients!

title: Extreme delay for appontment
body:
Tried to book appointment, none available for 2 weeks! Try ringing 1st thing for same day appointment, none available.
Next suggestion - come down to surgery at 8 & you'll then get same day appointment, could be any time during the day.
Don't get sick at this surgery & you'll be fine.

author: Thereals
title: Stonebridge centre
body:
Well I'm back again to air my grievances about Stonebridge centre and Nottingham city South mental health team. I do this without malice simply to reassure those with similar issues, out there, they are not alone. This is not a witch hunt, so I won't mention any names.  
I had been seeing a CPN at Stonebridge for over six months. Following a series of demeaning meetings and what I would call inaccuracies in the subsequent correspondences to my GP, decided, (with a heavy heart) that I did not wish to see this person anymore. This was about the end of October 2019 and was established with the service manager.  
After this time my mental health took a very big downturn and I managed to get to see the current locum psychiatrist. They assessed my current mental well-being and remarked that I was now at risk . This was of no surprise to me considering the fact that I had started to hear voices in my head and just prior to the appointment had been jumping in front of traffic, begging drivers to run me over.  
I was prescribed anti psychotics and promised an appointment early in the new year.  
Well to any readers out there you won't be surprised to hear that never happened. Iam having problems with the new medication and have talked to my GP about it, but it's beyond his realm of expertise.  
What really upsets me though is receiving an appointment from the CPN I said I found too difficult to work with, in the New Year. I think, after all ive been through they've not listened to a word I have said. I cancelled this, quite rightly, as far as I'm concerned this was a wrongly deployed, 'null appointment'.  
I received a letter yesterday saying I was about to be discharged in light of the fact that I cancelled the appointment with the original CPN. There was no mention of a psychiatrist appointment or alternatives to the CPN I broke ties with last October. I have been under the Stonebridge for well over 10 years, never known it so bad especially when as the psychiatrist said before Christmas -you are now at risk

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: KL-93
title: The staff were really reassuring
body: Newborn son had lump appear on his head. Was really worried and anxious but the staff were really reassuring and very friendly and helpful.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: Evied10
title: Broke my arm/elbow
body: I was riding my horse and it bucked and I fell off - I felt sad and in pain.

readBy.name: Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor service all round
body:
Been with surgery many year... its now worst it has ever been.. staff are rude inconsistent and talk to like you are a fool and then add nothing we can do darling at the end like they have been helpful.  
Yes there is a car park that you could use IF STAFF DIDNT PARK IN IT. 
Ask to speak to the practice manager and instead of a call to ask whats up, they send you a letter say we will look into your issues and get back to you.... but nobody asked what the issue is.
Listen to message and music on the phone waiting for call to be answered in which time you could get there quicker to find they are having a chin wag instead of picking up the calls.
Will call you to say test results say you have a problem but no GP appointment for 2 maybe 3 week to sort it out so in that time you could kill yourself with worry but hey dont care as they have 6 thousand other people to see.... well if you cant manage what you have close the list instead of being greedy. 
LOCUM doctors all the time, one good GP comes in and then leaves! 
Attitude of individuals is poor

title: Needs improvement
body:
Managed to get through at 08.30 when lines open, left on hold for 14mins & 48 seconds to be told no appointments. Explained have asthma and chest infection need to see GP today. Told nothing left after being left on hold for so long. Get offered and appointment on Wednesday great could end up worse or worse case in hospital when just seeing GP could prevent. 
Receptionist unfriendly almost could say sounded like couldn't care less. Finally asked do I want one of those on Wednesday before they go. 
I dont bother the surgery unless I really feel I need to see a GP and feel disappointed by the receptionists tones

title: Awful made to feel like a child.
body: Rang to ask for appointment to see a GP, receptionist gave appointment then said was to see Nurse prescriber. I said I’d prefer to see GP please, she then proceeded to launch into how the nurse was a highly trained professional can prescribe etc. I asked again to see a GP and was then met with a very very curt, ‘well I need to write on the computer why you won’t see the nurse so can you tell me why. The Doctor will want to know why you won’t see them’. I just replied that I will discuss it  with the GP when I go. I was Eventually  given an appointment but she remained very brusque and put the phone down! I know first hand how tightly squeezed NHS services are, it’s a battle one deals with everyday as a Health professional myself. The reasons for wanting to see a GP ? Well I shouldn’t have to justify that here but let’s just say, there may be more to a patient’s presentation than whether they need medication thrown at them. I know with my background, that I need to discuss my symptoms with a Doctor who has already referred me to Hospital. Even with my almost 40 years of clinical experience, I was left feeling very upset, demoralised and like a scalded child just for asking to see a Doctor. As I said, I fully understand the pressures of demand v capacity, and the direction which these staff may have been given by practice management teams, but these people in the main are not  trained in triage nor have clinical backgrounds and a patient, who is already feeling unwell enough to reach out, should not be made to feel this way. Sorry but from posts here too, this practice failing in at least 2 of the CQC 5 KLOe: Caring and Responsive. Thankfully the only saving grace is that when you do see a GP, they are very good but that cannot be said for the way in which this practice is managed not for the way in which patients are made to feel on contact.

author: Grateful orthopaedic patient
title: Very impressed with the Orthopaedic experience
body:
I was admitted through DOSA in Woodend Hospital. The care & attention my husband and I received there was exemplary. The Ortho experience from door to table,is very professional,caring and certainly very "slick ".We were introduced to surgeon Mr Mitchell,the anaesthetist,OT,Physio,and were kept informed of my surgery time, the staff were all so friendly and nothing was a bother.My named nurse was Louise, the charge nurse, be proud ,you and your staff are doing an amazing job. The anaesthetic room staff delivered a high standard of pre op care ,recovery care was also performed with the highest expertise.I was then admitted to Ward 10,and was discharged next day.After again review by Mr Mitchell,I had repeat bloods and X-ray done,was further reviewed by OT,Physio and chat with the pharmacist.  
I certainly am very impressed with the Orthopaedic experience, from out patient appt,pre assessment and the regular calls to admission.Thank you so much Mr Mitchell and your amazing team.We certainly are fortunate in NHS Grampian to have such an amazing Orthopaedic surgeon .

readBy.name: Office of Rhoda Grant, MSP for Highlands and Islands

title: Great practice and staff amazing
body:
My husband and I have been patients at the practice since 2012. We feel very lucky as the staff are friendly and helpful. We can get early morning appointments (around 7am) and also attend the walk in clinic which is a godsend for a working person. We have seen all of the doctors. One doctor has been especially helpful over the last few years. He really cares.
We have needed referrals, routine tests, prescriptions etc and the reception staff are responsive and send us results etc. The nurses have also been approachable and helpful

author: L-Smiley
title: Good care on stroke unit
body: I was sent to Berman 1 ward at Nottingham City Hospital after a fall and a day in the A & E department. I was to be investigated for a possible TIA. I arrived in the middle of the night but I was quickly made comfortable and assessed thoroughly. The care on the ward was really good. The general atmosphere was efficient but friendly, which gave me confidence that I would be treated well and thoroughly. The staff were all excellent, including doctors, nurses, HCAs, cleaners, therapists and everyone else too. All the necessary investigations were done and I wasn't sent home until the physiotherapist was assured that I could walk and manage the stairs, and the occupational therapist had tested me making a drink. This gave me confidence that I was safe to be discharged. The food was delicious and plentiful in the time I was there, and the staff found the time to interact with the patients. I would particularly mention the HCA called Janet. Nothing was too much trouble for her, from helping me to the bathroom to getting answers to my questions and she walked miles escorting me to and from my scans. There are so many problems with the NHS at the moment, but I can have no complaints about my stay on Berman 1 ward.

title: fantastic practice
body: I visited Chanctonbury ward on February 5th for an operation for a scaphoid fracture. I cannot praise enough the attention I received and never got a chance to thank all the nurses and  surgeons.

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Felicity swan
title: Impressive department
body:
I was nervous, I knew that this procedure is painful and was put at ease from the initial blood pressure.  
The walk to the room - it was explained who was in my room and what they do.  
The surgeon explained the procedure and did not rush me  
The team were professional and endeavoured to put me at ease which was not easy as I was very scared, they were chatty and pleasant  
The process was hideous however and I can’t believe that anaesthetic is not used which is de rigeur in USA it seems brutal in the extreme but I appreciate this is not a reflection of the team but a policy that really needs review.  
Clean, swift and very impressive department thank you

author: rp-20
title: Support from Nottingham City Mental Health Crisis Team
body: I have recently been the recipient of some excellent help from the above Crisis Team. They visited my home initially, speaking to myself and close members of my family, giving support and reassurance at a time when I was at my lowest. They visited daily until, by agreement, the visits were reduced to twice weekly and subsequently I visited the team on a weekly basis at Highbury Hospital out-patients department. My family and I felt that we were supported by kind, caring individuals, who were available at the end of a telephone at any time of the day or night. Their professionalism was always evident but was backed up with excellent interpersonal skills which I found both calming and reassuring. I have now been discharged from their care as I continue to recover but I and my immediate family cannot praise the work and dedication of this team highly enough.

author: Blondie20
title: Colposcopy appointment
body: My husband came with me to my colposcopy appointment  as I was extremely nervous and anxious. The staff were brilliant and put me at ease straight away. The consultant Mr Mohanty and nurses Amy and Anita were excellent and made me feel so much better and l was treated with dignity and care. The procedure didn't last long and it was absolutely fine and didnt hurt.

author: Stumpweasel
title: Extremely professional and friendly staff
body:
I was admited to Ward 18 (surgical recieving) on 6th Feb after midnight due to stomach probs.  
The nurses who admited me could not have been any nicer or welcoming.  
I was very ill and tbh scared but they soon made me feel alot less apprehensive and very much in capable hands. The porter too couldnt be more friendly or professional.  
The day shift were no different.  
Extremely professional and friendly. Everyone i had contact with, nurses, domestics, radiographers, porters and doçtors made my stay as comfortable as possible.  
Everything was explained well and because i was feeling so ill i wasnt very helpful when it came to being examined. But they all took their time to help and let me do things in my own time.  
Wishaw General and the residents of South Lanarkshire is lucky to have such wonderful people working there.  
Thankyou very much. We might not have gotten to the bottom of whats causing my problems yet but ive no doubt they will in due course through outpatients.

title: Great Doctor, seen very quickly
body:
Called automated system Sunday, and got a telephone consult with the doctor for Monday morning. He needed to see me and was able to give me an appointment that morning and blood tests were arranged for the same morning. This system appears to work extremely efficiently for quick access to my GP. The doctor himself was excellent. He assessed what were a couple of sensitive issues directly and respectfully, and I was very satisfied with the advice and outcomes. Another very positive experience of my local practice I’ve been coming to for 5 years now, and I’ve always been very happy with the service.
Much appreciated!

author: Daughter A
title: Exemplary rehabilitation team - this is how it should be done !
body:
My mother was recently admitted to hospital as an emergency with severe pneumonia, which was complicated by a partially collapsed left lung and a very low serum sodium level, which had made her extremely confused and, eventually, unable to walk or stand. Before her admission, she had been socially active and a regular attender at local groups and family events, although deafness and slowly declining mobility sometimes made life challenging for her.  
She was admitted via Accident and Emergency into a medical assessment ward in January (probably the worst time of year to be admitted I feel, when acute services are under maximum pressure), then had several ward moves during her short admission. After a few days, she was medically fit for discharge, but remained a shadow of her former self. At discharge, she was referred to the Wishaw Rehabilitation Team under the 'Discharge to Assess' programme.  
Within two hours of discharge, she was assessed by an Occupational Therapist who gave us lots of helpful advice, always based on my mother's own wishes and needs. She then very rapidly organised personal home care services to help with washing and dressing in the morning and evening, hand rails to enable my mum to access her bedroom and bathroom upstairs, walking aids for both upstairs and downstairs, toilet adaptations, a key box, community alarm and inputs from wider team members, including a physiotherapist, the sensory care team and the local fire service.  
This story is about the excellent person centred care delivered by this team, which is an example of the type of high quality rehabilitation services that enable people who are at high risk of being readmitted to hospital to remain in their own home.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Heart
title: Heart attack
body:
One evening in September 2019 I felt a pain in my chest, pressure and tightening. I also felt pain in my back, down my left arm and in my jawline. My forehead was clammy and cold to the touch. I had no idea what was happening but I knew it was not right to feel this way. I telephoned NHS 24 and the call handler relayed the information to a nurse who decided to send an ambulance for me.  
The ambulance arrived some time later and the paramedics sprayed the GTN spray under my tongue and gave me an aspirin to chew. They carried out an ECG in my bedroom before taking me to Wishaw General Hospital. When I arrived in A&E I underwent various tests and procedures; one of which was a TROP(Troponin?) Test to assess the level in my blood. This test was repeated after 5/6 hours and the doctor reported t me that because there had been a 40% difference in the two readings I had had a heart attack!  
I was transferred to the Emergency Care Ward to be monitored and was again informed that I had had a heart attack. I was then moved to the Respiratory Ward on Monday under a consultant. I underwent other tests/scans etc and each doctor I saw told me I had had a heart attack. I did not see the consultant until Wednesday afternoon when I was told that I had not had a heart attack. I was delighted at the news but queried why several other doctors had told me that I had had a heart attack. The doctor appeared perplexed and bewildered as to why I would be told such a thing! The doctor then said that on paper I had had a heart attack; but that they weren't convinced"!!! The doctor then arranged for me to have a test for a Pulmonary Embolism. As this doctor was then off duty it was one of the other doctors who told me on Thursday morning that the test for a clot had come back negative so they were going to be treating me for the heart - no mention of a heart attack this time! I was to have a treadmill test but it was broken and it would not be repaired until at least the following Thursday. The doctor asked if I would stay in hospital for a week until the treadmill was fixed; believing that the test would have been done quicker with me as an in patient. However I requested to be allowed to go home and after taking some advice the doctor agreed. The was at the end of September 2019.  
I received a letter from the hospital inviting me to attend for a treadmill test on in early October. On the morning of the appointment I received a telephone call to tell me that due to sickness absence within the department my appointment was postponed and I would receive another in the near future.  
Two days later in the evening of Wednesday I experienced the same symptoms that I had when I was first admitted. I telephoned NHS 24 and they sent an emergency ambulance for me. When I arrived in A&E the doctor enquired why I had not used my GTN spray and I said I didn't have one. The doctor said that I should never have been dismissed in September without a spray. I explained what was happening and what had happened previously and that I had been told there was no changes in any ECG's and nothing unusual. The doctor came back to tell me I was being admitted to ECU and said that my previous ECG did show something in my upper ??? and lower ??? were ??? - and that they just thought I might want to know that! Another consultant arranged for me to have a treadmill test which I could not do and therefore there was not a definitive reading. I was then moved to the Coronary Ward.  
Once in the Coronary Ward I realised that I was across the corridor from someone I knew - this was not acceptable under the circumstances. The consultant who would be assessing my case but be was otherwise engaged asked another consultant to see me and assess if I needed to stay in hospital. The consultant provided me with a very comprehensive and detailed description of indigestion and heartburn and suggested that my medication was now - after years - affecting my stomach and that he would change my prescription and add an indigestion tablet to help my indigestion and sent me home the day after I was admitted.  
I received a letter to go for a CT Angiogram in December at the Golden Jubilee Hospital. I attended the appointment and the result is that I have Coronary Artery Disease; the doctor at the Jubilee, Scotland's National Hospital, said that if I was their patient they would be arranging for a balloon and a stent to be inserted. The report was forwarded to University Hospital Wishaw General and it has been decided that I do not require any angioplasty at this time and I have been invited to a clinic in March 2020.  
I believe that time is of the essence and it is unacceptable that different health professionals have different opinions and because of this I feel am at the mercy of whatever comes into their mind that day. It strikes me as an abuse of power and is morally unacceptable.  
Please investigate. I look forward to your response.

author: Anw-20
title: My stay on Castle Ward
body:
Approximately one year ago I was a patient on Castle Ward Worthing Hospital.  
It has taken all this time to feel mentally able to write this review.  
The doctor at A&E was very good but my nightmare began as soon as I was taken up to Castle Ward.  
I am elderly and was poorly and I feel that because of this, the staff treated me as if I was a baby or demented as if I had lost my marbles. Sometimes they would shout at me for things that I could not help like knocking things over. I often asked about my medical condition and no one would tell me which made me feel very anxious. My relatives had no joy either and were quite often kept in the dark.  
Quite often I would feel very thirsty but my drink was out of reach. Everytime I asked a member of staff for it, I felt like I was being a nuisance. One day my mouth was very sore and dry and a nurse put my tablets in my mouth without a drink and they got stuck on the roof of my mouth instead of going down. This caused me even more pain. My relatives tried to complain about it but felt they were treated as a nuisance too.  
The nights were really long and also the days. I only had my visits from my relatives to look forward to and was often close to tears when they arrived. I was made to go to bed at 7pm.  
This would not seem quite so bad if the staff seemed like they were too busy, but I quite often observed them chatting together which included talking about "nuisance patients and relatives" which I could hear every word. They also talked about other staff members.  
I was so relieved to be discharged home even though I still felt poorly. I have instructed my family to make certain that I never go to that particular hospital again.  
If you have an elderly relative keep them away from Castle Ward.

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: I was given unclear instructions.
body: During my appointment for my echocardiogram, I first asked for my mum to leave the room but instead the staff member took it upon themselves to just draw a curtain even though when I inevitably had to walk out from the curtain my mum would see me. I was then asked to take off my top half clothing and then put on an orange cape that ties at the front, I asked the staff member what I’m actually supposed to do with it because I was very confused as there was no sleeves like I had expected and they was saying to put it over my shoulders so I did and I walked out and they said I needed to take off my sports bra too. I said is there no way I can keep it on and they said no because the gel needs to be rubbed on the heart area and they pointed to where that was on themselves and it would be right under the nipple so this to me as an insecure 17 year old girl rang massive alarm bells so I refused the whole thing. I wanted to wear a gown not a cape that would reveal and show everything, the staff member said it’s the least invasive test but the cape only covered my back whilst my whole chest would have been exposed and if it was supposed to cover my front then there would have been no way that they could have rubbed the gel on. This was all very confusing for me and I wish I was given some clear instructions. Afterwards they attempted to guilt trip me by saying how it’s one of the least invasive tests so they was confused why I wouldn’t cooperate but from the instructions given I was expected to walk out in front of the staff member and my mum with my boobs completely out which is something I’m not prepared to do. The whole thing was a mess.

author: Hazvog
title: Helpful, efficient and dignified
body:
Staff were helpful, efficient and thoughtful. The experience felt dignified. The only down side was that discussing patient cases was not very private. Apart from that everything else was a positive experience and I would not be worried about having another surgery in the Day Case Unit. I would also recommend the Day Surgery Unit to others.  
Thank you.

author: Julie B
title: Safeguarding Concern
body: Unfortunately, I had cause for complaint on three separate occasions regarding the standard of care provided to my father by A1 Homecare Ltd. The final, most serious, complaint resulted in an investigation by Essex Social Service with an eventual outcome of fully substantiated safeguarding concerns. I feel both the standard of care provided and their policies and procedures need improvement.

author: defenderrd83
title: The quick response made a world of difference.
body: My father, who had Parkinson’s Disease, gradually developed problems with swallowing and his GP referred him to SALT. When his swallow got suddenly worse, the GP escalated the referral to “ urgent” and, to our amazement we were contacted the next morning ( a Friday) by a therapist who came immediately. Lucy was excellent in all that she did. The fact that she responded so quickly made a world of difference to what turned out to be my dad’s end of life care. She confirmed the problem which then allowed his GP to discuss ongoing treatment v palliative care with dad. This then allowed everything to be organised for end of life care at home and the whole system kicked into place fantastically with amazing care from district nurses and Marie curie nurses

readBy.name: Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

title: Great Service
body: Arrived early and was seen on time. Was booked in at West Byfleet Health Centre for ultrasound of thyroid. The Dr who saw me was lovely and completely put me at ease. He was very thorough and talked to me through the entire procedure. Very knowledgeable and let me know that there were no abnormalities found.  A great service.

author: Ooooooooooooooooooo
title: Cystoscopy Procedure
body:
Staff in all departments excellent. Everything explained well and carried out as explained. An excellent professional team.  
I feel it is stressful and unnecessary however to have patients arrive 5 hours before the procedure takes place. Although I understand the need to fast before an anesthetic is administered, I do not think it is of any benefit to patients or staff to be sitting immobile for such an extended period of time in a hospital ward.  
My Pre Assessment was carried out 48 hours before the actual procedure and therefore there was unlikely to be any significant change in my suitability to undergo a General Anesthetic. I would have been more comfortable and less tense if I could have been given a time slot where I underwent the procedure in under 5 hours after my arrival.  
I understand that at times delays can occur due to unforeseen circumstances however on the day procedures were carried out as planned and there were no emergency circumstances involved in this waiting time and I was informed this is normal practice for this clinic.  
[Unsure about 'Appointments']

title: An administrative backwards step
body:
I recently re-joined this practice and was so pleased to be able to attend somewhere that was previously accessible, and enabled me to look after my health and fit in appointments around work etc. 

However, the recent administrative changes are an absolute nightmare. You can only email the surgery via the NHS app, and there is a 2 working day SLA for a response. The process is cumbersome; you have to effective self-diagnose when choosing options so it is easy to get led down the wrong path. 

There is no option to pre-book future appointments for non-urgent matters so cannot fit these in around work and other commitments. Truly awful system. 

Staff are all generally great but after being back for 2 months, I'm already looking for another practice.

author: Davy Crockett
title: Extremely long wait
body: I have progressive ms and have now been waiting 20 months for a follow up appointment with consultant. I feel abandoned and have little hope of getting any help to improve my quality of life. this obviously affects my family also. It would help to know what is going on at Musgrove.

readBy.name: Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fabulous Department,
body: I've just had my wisdom teeth removed along with a couple of others under local anesthetic, the staff were friendly and instantly put you at ease and on the day they were punctual and fast seeing me on time and no delays, I can honestly say I've had no problems with the healing process they did a brilliant job, thankyou,

readBy.name: Countess of Chester Hospital NHS Foundation Trust.

title: Lack of information and difficult to contact
body:
Was not told properly about how the appointment would work in that I needed a further appointment for a different clinic before starting treatment and was not informed of fasting blood tests needed before attending. 

Needed to change my appointment of further clinic date and unable to get a hold of them when I rang throughout the day/week

readBy.name: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

author: Thsnful
title: Wee faint in X-ray department
body:
I had a wee turn when leaving the Xray Dept. I wasn't a patient there, I was accompanying my husband.  
I was scooped up onto a trolley and taken to A&E where I was seen immediately. From start to finish I received excellent care and compassion. From the nurse in Xray who took me to A&E, to Dr MacNeil, who's care and attention to detail could not be faulted,...., to the nurse who took me for CT Scan, radiologist, nurses who looked after me in the cubicle in A&E, I can only say the care and attention was absolutely First Class. I was very lucky, I was ok, but so many really sick people go through your doors, and if they all get the treatment I got, then it goes a long way to helping you feel safe and secure. My heartfelt thanks to you all.

readBy.name: Office of Rhoda Grant, MSP for Highlands and Islands

title: Awful
body: The surgery is an absolute disgrace! Never see the same doctor more than once. Nothing ever seems to be on record. Can never get an appointment and receptionist are always rude and act like you are an inconvenience. Went today for an URGENT appointment for my 2 year old, only to be told when I am in the waiting room that her appointment has been cancelled and they will reschedule it for Thursday. Completely unacceptable!

title: Great practice.
body: I find doctors give enough time to discuss all matters adequately and comprehensively  within the time allocated. Lovely to be a patient of this surgery.

title: Lovely nurses and doctors
body: Always have a lovely experience when I have an appointment. Really friendly nurses and doctors and always go out their way to make sure you’re happy before you leave.

title: Great practice
body: Really helpful and professional.  Appointments are quickly available.  They have a really nice centre.

author: Toddler mum
title: Discharged at 4am
body: A few weeks ago I ended up in A& E suffering from severe headaches and nausea/sickness when vertical. The doctors initially seemed concerned and asked me to stay in overnight, but at 4am, before I had been moved to the ward I was then told that they weren't too concerned, and was discharged without any answers. My husband had already gone home to look after our 16 month old, so I was left to get a taxi in the middle of the night (I am a 33 year old woman and couldn't be in a vertical position without being sick-which I of course was in the taxi). I found this quite a traumatic experience, and also had no answers, and had to return home to my toddler which is a challenging situation when you have to remain lying down.

readBy.name: Torbay and South Devon NHS Foundation Trust
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

title: Good service
body: All staff very helpful including receptionist, nurses and doctors. Do not have problems making an appointment.

author: Toddler mum
title: Exceptional care
body:
I attended A&E but was discharged as they were not worried. After little improvement, I then returned to A&E the following weekend on the advice of 111 when I developed double vision in addition to the previous symptoms. This time I was told almost straight away after seeing the doctor in A&E that I wouldn't be leaving until they had an answer. He gave me a very thorough examination and my husband and I were so relieved to be taken seriously.  
I was then introduced to a doctor named Charlotte, based on EAU3 who again gave me a thorough examination and decided to admit me to the EAU3 unit overnight so that she could oversee my care the following day. She arranged for a number of different tests to take place quickly and thoroughly and they managed to find the cause of the problem, which it turned out was a dural leak, causing hypotension in my head. I remained in EAU3 for 3 nights and over that time Charlotte made sure that I was thoroughly investigated, informed and looked after throughout. She even went out of her way on her day off the ward to come down a number of times to do a lumbar puncture and to keep me in the loop regarding my progress.  
After a worrying week and our experience the previous weekend of feeling like we were wasting the hospital's time, both I and my family were extremely grateful to receive such comprehensive attention and care from Charlotte, and to be communicated with so considerately doing what we believe was going over and above what she was expected to do. When I left the hospital this time I felt confident that I knew what to expect moving forward and that I would be looked after if symptoms continued.  
I would also like to mention Dr Baird who I also found to be both attentive, and considerate in the way he communicated with me.  
I would just like to say a huge thank you in particular to Charlotte, but also to Dr Baird and to the Doctor who I met in triage that day, for putting my mind at rest, taking my symptoms seriously and for looking after me so well over the few days I was in.  
[Very happy with 'Being listened to']  
  
[Very happy with 'Explanations']

readBy.name: Torbay and South Devon NHS Foundation Trust

title: Appointments difficult
body:
Doctors excellent.
Nurses excellent.
Reception staff good.
But trying to phone for an appointment is hopeless. I started phoning three minutes before they opened and kept redialing for thirty five minutes before I could get through. Just to be told all appointments were gone.
With breathing difficulty I thought that very bad service from an otherwise excellent surgery.

author: lottie123
title: Excellent care
body: Removal of lump from ear and skin graft. Care from Doctor and nurses excellent.

title: Website
body:
Trying to access website to order repeat prescriptions.  After 4 hours have given up and will drop requests in.
What is the point of an online service if it doesn’t work.
Don’t know how non-mobile patients cope.

author: Rival
title: Nothing but praise for this service
body:
I have nothing but praise for the NHS service from GP to the Dermatology Unit at RCH Treliske Hospital. I discovered a lump on my face, saw the GP who immediately referred me for consultation with Dr Black at the outpatients unit in Truro. He was friendly, put me at complete ease and explained the lump would need to be removed. Within 16 days I attended Treliske for the lump to be removed by Associate Specialist Dermatology, Dr Bailey. Dr Bailey immediately put me at ease explaining the procedure fully and skilfully removed the lump. The only thing I felt was the needle prick of the local anaesthetic and now four days later have removed the dressing to find a well healing cut with no pain.  
The stitches are to be removed later this week and hopefully no further treatment will be required.

title: Appalling waiting times
body:
I have been registered at the practice for nearly 2 years now and getting an appointment has always been a battle. However, I have always been patient and understand the strain/ difficulties GP's currently face.  
Recently I was was reffered to make an appointment and the earlist one avalible at the practice was in almost 3 week. With no other choice I took this appointment.  On the day of the appointment, i recieved a texy message in the morning saying my appointment has been cancelled (due to staffing issues) and that i need to call and rearrage.  Upon doing so i was advided that the earlist appoinemnt was another 3 weeks away.  The fact that i had initially waited 3 weeks for the original appointment and my concers for health were totally disreguarded. 
Given that appointment are so difficult to get and waiting times are a matter of weeks, the practice is advertising that they are taking on new patients.  Surley this shouldn't be happening.

title: Delighted this is my local hospital
body: Rush hour visit to A&E on 23rd December, feeling guilty as we are told how over stretched the staff are in A&E.  Seen straight away  in triage by a lovely ANP who then treated my severe pressure and pain in my eye, despite being busy she was so attentive and checked with on call Dr due to previous eye surgery many years ago.  She also ensured I was seen the next day by medical team despite that being Xmas eve.  Amazingly caring, professional and efficient.  Thank you so much.

title: Un helpful reception
body:
All I can say is , and I'm having to choose my words carefully , The person I spoke with today when I rang 
 was rude and very very unhelpful and I still didn't get an appointment booked due to above person basically ending our conversation abruptly. Not impressed and this is not the first time I have encountered a  rude and  unhelpful person on the phone at this practice .

author: Cheery chap
title: Wonderful treatment
body: I was recently diagnosed with a Basal Cell Carcinoma on my chest. This was first spotted by my GP who got me an appointment at Ninewells hospital. Within a short time I had an appointment with the surgeons at Ninewells. They confirmed the diagnosis and explained what treatment would be required. They were at pains to put me at ease and explain any questions I had. I received my treatment on 11 December. All of the staff on the day were terrific, things were running a little late but I was kept informed as to what was happening. The operation itself was a complete success and I later received a phone call verifying that all of the BSC had been removed. Receiving the call saved me a trip to Ninewells and gave me the good news sooner rather than later. The treatment received was top class and all the staff I came into contact with were professional and courteous. Whilst it is never good to have these operations I can only applaud the staff and treatment I received from both my GP and Ninewells Hospital.

title: RubbIsh
body: Was told by healthshare that the results of my scan showed a partial tear in my plantar fascia and that I was being referred to the Nuffield for injections or surgery but when I got to the Nuffield my appointment was with a physio, which I didn't need, who couldn't access my scan as it was done by a private company and I've got to start the process all over again, phoned pals to complain and they said that healthshare should have referred me to a consultant and sent my scan over. Wasted over 5 months, so painful I can hardly walk. Luckily the Nuffield rushed through an MRI just waiting for result.

title: Diabolical
body:
Since being taken over by the Haxby Group, the level of care at Burnbrae Surgery has plummeted.
I had a blood test at the end of December and have still (it's now the 10th of February) not had the results back nor a successful appointment to see a doctor.
When they didn't contact me and after I spent an afternoon on the phone unable to get through, I visited the surgery and was told by the receptionist that the results were not good and that I would need to discuss them with a doctor.
She then told me that all she was able to offer was a telephone call during my work hours and in 3 weeks time; the call never came.
They then offered me an extended hours appointment at Bransholme Health Centre which I attended this last weekend only to be told by the doctor there that he had no access on his computer to my test results.
They are useless, profiteering racketeers who treat their clients with little to no concern or individuality preferring the McDonalds approach to NHS 'care'.
As has been stated already in another review, their reception staff leave much to be desired in terms of manners, often doing their uppermost to discourage anyone from wanting an appointment and making you all-but beg at a time when you might already be feeling low and vulnerable.
This isn't the first time that I or my family have been treated like this - my daughter was also treated very poorly last year, requiring 2 appointments for a routine matter that could have been dealt with in 1 appointment had the consultant done their job properly in the first instance.

author: Blinkcart
title: All of the staff on this ward were excellent.
body:
It is very hard to convey in words just how good my stay on this ward was.  
I had a total knee replacement in January and was told to report to ward 15 Burnley General Hospital.  
Everybody on this ward from the surgeon to the sister, nurses to auxiliary, porters to the catering staff were excellent  
I can’t say anyone by name otherwise I would have to name everyone the care and bedside manner was exemplary.  
I have in the past been an inpatient at MRI and BRH this was by far the most enjoyable stay  
I thank them all

title: Outstanding practice
body:
The new online service has taken your patient care and response times to very high levels indeed.
I have been a patient since 1998 abd recently have had a bad chest infection.
i have had cause to ask for several phone calls and appointments since 19.01.20 and the response time,patient care and action taken was most impressive
every doctor i have seen or spoke to has calmed me down and allayed my fears and taken investigations further
well done to you all

author: Sweet April
title: Anxiety prior to urological investigations
body: I was absolutely terrified about the prospect of having the procedure done, I told the nurse how anxious I was feeling and she comforted me and promised to stay with me throughout. She got another nurse to attend as well. The nurse held my hand all the time and reassured me and the other nurse also comforted me.   They were wonderful and I can't praise them enough

author: Soph12
title: Endoscopy
body: Staff made me feel at ease.

author: Pm1234
title: Seen quickly
body: Came to minor injuries to be checked over. Was seen quickly staff were lovely were seen by Elaine and she was brilliant. And cut out hours of waiting in accident and emergency!

author: Daughter- L
title: My mother's experience
body:
My mother is 88 years old and was admitted into Wishaw General Hospital in January, suffering from pneumonia. Despite the hospital being extremely busy, resulting in all the hospital staff being seriously overworked, my mum was consistently treated with kindness and respect, and provided with the appropriate medical assistance she required.  
Since returning home, she has been looked after within a rehabilitation programme and has had excellent help from agencies including occupational therapy and physiotherapy. All the professionals involved have been extremely knowledgeable, kind and respectful.  
The overall treatment and support which my mum has received have been exemplary.

title: Rude receptionist
body: Phoned the practice this morning I was spoken to by a very rude receptionist they were curt and abrupt

title: Excellent Supporter
body: Excellent staff and a great service. My supporter was really good and I'm now a big fan of the talking therapies service. More needs to be done to make more aware of this great service so they too can benefit from it.

title: Lovely practice
body: Very pleasant greeting on arrival, did not have to wait more than 5 mins before being seen , doctor very friendly and explained everything that he needed to do. All in all a very relaxing atmosphere. Would definitely recommend.

author: Sunshine90
title: No one told me
body: 5 years ago I underwent different test for coeliac disease and nothing had came from it. Went for a Dr's appointment last week for something unrelated with an advanced nurse practitioner to be told my notes read that I tested positive for coeliac. No one had told me this information despite repeated contacts with hospital consultant and my gp. Why has this happened, I don't know what to do next.

title: The food is diabolical
body: I cannot fault the staff both clinical and domestic who cared for me during my recent 8 day stay. However I feel the food situation needs a massive review. Being on the SAU for most of my stay the menu choices were severely limited to what amounted to jacket potatoes or soup or even worse cup a soups. For most of my stay I was on liquids or fluids only so only had to endure one jacket potato which was truly vile. Dry and tasteless accompanied by a pot of extremely fishy smelling tuna. The most concerning episode was after I had my procedure and was transferred to another ward. When lunch was being served as I was not there the day before I was told I would have to have what was left. I then asked for a bowl of soup as I was trying to build my diet up to liquids from free fluids. What I was actually served was mince potatoes and sweet corn. Hardly a liquid diet. My daughter took me down to the restaurant and bought me a yogurt for my lunch. For dinner I was served chicken curry. Once again not appropriate. I had some cup a soups with me so asked for someone to add some water to it for me. At no time was I offered an alternative and thank the Lord was discharged the same evening. I am now at home recovering eating some homemade nutritious real food. Food is medicine as well

author: am20
title: My son's emergency surgery
body: My son has a profound learning disability & had to attend the Surgical Admissions Unit 2 at the Victoria Hospital to have surgery in Feb. The understanding we received from everyone from the ladies on the NHS 24 line, the GP who did the home visit, the nurses who gave us a private room, hospital staff, doctors & the anaesthetist who came up with a brilliant idea to actually get him into theatre, was exceptional. There really are not enough words to express my gratitude, so thank you all from the bottom of my heart.

title: Nice clean modern surgery-the people let it down
body: I’ve never been seen one time, at best they’ve been 30 minutes late, the receptionists are usually rude, the doctors don’t really care and I’ve had one look up symptoms on the internet, and they (on two occasions) have got my appointment time wrong. The surgery is lovely and modern and lots of seats in the waiting area. I can’t fault the midwives, however I don’t believe they belong to the actual surgery.

title: Awful
body:
You could stand in front of the receptionist for 15 mins before she even acknowledges your standing there like an idiot. 

They never answer the phone and the practice manager is often chatting rubbish with the receptionists. 

I’ve been sat waiting on the phone for 45 mins now and have been caller number 3 in the que for that whole time. It’s 2pm. 

I hate having to deal with this surgery it’s beyond frustrating.

title: Worst doctors ever
body: I do not recommend this practice, I recommend you go to one of the others locally and save yourself a massive headache. I have unfortunately been with the practice for over 4 years now and I’ve watched it go from a half decent practice to a shocking excuse of a practice, if you want a appointment, you can’t get one for at least a month in advance, if you need a referral they make you wait a eternity and by the time you get it, your problem is extremely out of control! The only positive thing I have to say about this practice is there have been a few decent receptionists that have tried their best to get things done despite being against the currant. I truly hope they see sense and get work elsewhere, I’ve seen better doctors offices in a derelict building with no power! I don’t know how they thought they were going to deal with 4 practices but 1 phone number?? All they cared about was taking the money that came with it and didn’t care about the consequences for the patients, I really hope someone does something about this shoddy service and rectifies the problem for all the patients in all the practices linked to this awful service. I know this won’t happen though and that’s why I’m leaving now before they ruin my health any further

title: Wonderful Nason Ward!
body: Recovering at home after a recent appendectomy and wanted to express my heartful gratitude to all involved in my care. Thank you to the Surgeon and truly caring, calming theatre staff in an anxious situation! I really want to commend the staff on Nason Ward who were all wonderful, from the lovely nurses, so busy, but always ready to help and answer questions to the fabulous ladies( and gentleman!) who were involved in our day to day care. They were always smiling and their gentleness and kindness helped us all to feel better! Thank you all so much. Dee Dexter.

title: Fantastic presccription request response
body:
Ordered a repeat prescription late Sunday evening via NHS app.
Item required was approved.and electronically transmitted by the practise ready for collection  at a local pharmacy early the following day. Great service by both the practice and pharmacy at the nearby supermarket

title: Unprofessional manners from GP
body:
The GP has treated my health concerns inappropriately, rushing through the appointment and specifying that the surgery only gives 10 mins per patient and other people were waiting outside (please note I was seen 40 minutes after my appointment time). The same GP also stated that "was under pressure" and that I should undress quickly for a check-up and after that leave the room asap.  I don't think this is the right approach for a person in this position, it is disrespectful and really shows the lack of interest they have towards patients, when they should be the ones caring and reassuring them. 
Needless to say, I am very disappointed by the service and behaviour of this GP at this practice.
People often take time off work and are worried about their own conditions and are in pain, the last thing they need is someone making them feel uncomfortable.
